title: 107_s1196
content: The "Small Business Investment Company Amendments Act of 2001" amends subsidy fees and conflicts of interest regulations in the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. Subsidy fees are adjusted to not exceed 1.38 percent per year, effective October 1, 2001. Conflicts of interest disclosure requirements are modified by removing the clause related to disclosure in the locality most directly affected by the transaction. SEC. 3. CONFLICTS OF INTEREST amended by removing disclosure clause related to locality most affected by transaction. SEC. 4. PENALTIES FOR FALSE STATEMENTS. SEC. 4. PENALTIES FOR FALSE STATEMENTS. Amends criminal penalties for false statements related to small business investment companies and the Small Business Administration. Also amends civil penalties under the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989. SEC. 5. REMOVAL OR SUSPENSION OF MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS. Amends the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 to define 'management official' and outline the process for removal based on violations of the Act, regulations, or cease-and-desist orders. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 defines a 'management official' and outlines the process for their removal for substantial breaches of fiduciary duty involving personal dishonesty. A notice of intention to remove a management official must state the grounds and schedule a hearing within 30 to 60 days. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows for the removal of a management official for breaches of fiduciary duty. If the official does not appear at a hearing, consent is assumed, and an order of removal may be issued by the Administrator. The order becomes effective after 30 days of service to the licensee and official concerned. The Administrator shall render a decision within 90 days after the case is submitted for final decision and issue orders consistent with the provisions of the Act. The Administrator may modify, terminate, or set aside any order issued under this section. The Administrator has the authority to modify, terminate, or set aside any order issued under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. Judicial review of an order issued under this section shall be exclusively as provided in this subsection. Any party to a hearing may obtain a review of any order issued pursuant to the Act. The Administrator has the authority to modify, terminate, or set aside any order issued under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. Any party to a hearing may obtain a review of the order by filing a petition in the court of appeals within 30 days. The court shall transmit a copy of the petition to the Administrator, who will file the record in the proceeding. Upon filing a petition, the court gains jurisdiction over the matter. Upon filing a petition, the court gains exclusive jurisdiction to affirm, modify, terminate, or set aside the Administrator's order. The court's judgment is final but subject to review by the Supreme Court. Judicial review does not act as a stay on proceedings. The court has exclusive jurisdiction to review the Administrator's order, with the Supreme Court having the final say. Judicial review does not automatically stay any orders issued by the Administrator. SEC. 6. REDUCTION OF FEES. Two-Year Reduction of Section 7(a) Fees: Guarantee fees for loans approved during a 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, will have reduced rates based on the total loan amount. Annual fees for loans approved during the same period will also be adjusted. Annual fees for loans approved during a 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, will be reduced to 0.25 percent of the outstanding balance of the deferred participation share of the loan. Additionally, Section 504 fees will not exceed 50 percent of the established amount for loans made during the same 2-year period. During a 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, fees for loans approved will be reduced to 0.25 percent of the outstanding balance. Section 504 fees will not exceed 50 percent of the established amount for loans made during the same period. Assistance under loans or financings by the Small Business Administration will be treated as separate programs for budgetary purposes. Amendments to section 503 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 will be effective based on available appropriations. The amendments to section 503 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 will only be effective if funds are available under appropriations Acts to offset the cost. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2002.
